Hi Mike,

Mike Frayn wrote:

>I am having an issue with species (and population) stagnation in my latest 
>experiment and so I have been looking at the speciation components of NEAT 
>quite intently.  I have a couple of questions regarding the fitness penalty 
>for species that have gone past the dropoff_age point with no improvement.
>
>In the C++ version of NEAT that I downloaded, there doesn't seem to be any 
>check to see if the species being penalized is one of the top (if not *the* 
>top) performers.  The literature I've read on NEAT says "in order to prevent 
>stagnation, the lowest performing species over N generations old [is] not 
>allowed to reproduce".  I don't see any such checks for "lowest performing 
>species".  This leads into my second question.
>  
>
Yeh I can't see anything obvious. It's possible that this change was 
made after the version of code you have. One for Ken I think. This topic 
(culling elite species in general) came up a while ago during work on 
SharpNEAT. I switched sharpneat from culling the best species, just as 
any other, to preserving them indefinitely. That way the user gets to 
decide when to give up on the best species (by stopping the search) 
rather than some arbitrary number of generations in the search 
algorithm(or config file). Taking a fresh look at this it would seem 
sensible to have two stagnation values - one for the elite and for for 
all other species. You could then set a zero value for the elite to 
prevent culling occuring on those if you wanted, depending on the type 
of experiment.

>If this is in fact the case, that no checks are made, then surely the 
>population stagnancy check would not do much good, no?  The idea here seems 
>to be not to allow any species to reproduce except for the top two if the 
>entire population has not improved best fitness over N+5 generations (C++ 
>version again).  Surely, since the best species would have been sterile -5 
>generations ago, at this point, only allowing it and the one below it to 
>reproduce won't have much more of an effect than allowing any species to 
>reproduce.
>  
>
The basic idea is that species that have not improved for N generations 
will have their fitness greatly reduced by dividing by a large number 
(100 in Ken's code). This means they are less likely to be selected as 
the source of genetic material for the next generation. However, if the 
whoe population has stagnated, then they all will by adjusted by the 
same amount and therefore the algorithm runs just as if none of them 
were adjusted - since the selection algorithm selects genomes/species 
based on their relative fitness.

I'm not sure I understood your query exactly, but hopefully that sheds 
some light on the issue.

Colin
